author: adiasg
content:
What are the considerations around setting the gas limit? E.g., maintaining a target sync speed, maintaining a target idle time between blocks, limiting state growth etc.? 

Which of these considerations is the bottleneck for increasing the gas limit?

author: sky.cactus
content: IMO the metric to target is "consumer hardware".  Unfortunately, we blew past this metric a long time ago and have ceased even trying at this point.  ðŸ˜¢

author: sky.cactus
content: "Consumer hardware" here means computers that the average person already has (laptop, desktop, etc.) and where the requirements are low enough that they can run an Ethereum client in the background while continuing to use their computer for its normal tasks.

author: sky.cactus
content: The biggest barrier to this at the moment is the disk space.  Consumer laptops and desktops tend to have 512GB drives these days, and some significant portion of that is used for OS, games, photos, videos, etc.  If a client can't fit into 256GB, it probably is already out of reach for most consumers.

author: sky.cactus
content: I would be willing to accept "gaming rig" as the baseline we target, if we made a credible commitment to that.  Though, even gaming rigs likely only have ~1TB drives in them on average is my guess, and at least half of that is filled with games leaving ~512GB for an Ethereum Client (on the high end).

author: sky.cactus
content: We also, of course, need to be mindful of bandwidth and CPU usage.  At the moment I don't think Ethereum is particularly egregious on either of those fronts.  However, it would be easy for us to design things that cause consumers to not be able to handle those loads.

author: potuz
content: More than what is the target hardware I think the question was what is the bottleneck, and treat the target hardware as an outside parameter. From your reply I infer that state growth is what worries you the most.
